title: Enhancing Sleep Quality for Nursing Home Residents With Dementia: Pragmatic Trial of an Evidence-Based Frontline Huddling Program
description_brief: This was a pilot study (R61) to prepare for a full clinical trial (R33) aiming to improve clinical outcomes for an important, growing, and vulnerable population-nursing home (NH) residents with Alzheimer's disease or related dementias (ADRDs). The goal was to pilot and refine the research methods and intervention that would be subsequently evaluated in a full implementation trial (hybrid type III). The goal of the evidence-based intervention (LOCK) that was refined in this pilot study and will be evaluated in the subsequent full clinical trial is to improve the sleep of NH residents with ADRD.
description_detailed:
In community (non-VA) NHs \[one from each of 3 national NH corporations\], the multi-disciplinary research team achieved two aims: (1) refined the LOCK program to focus on sleep for residents with ADRD during this pilot (R61) phase, (2) which prepared the team for the second phase of this two-part NIA-funded grant (the R33 phase) to test the impact and sustainability of this intervention for NH residents with ADRD in an incomplete stepped-wedge randomized controlled trial.

THIS PILOT STUDY R61 PHASE (1 YEAR; N = 3 NHS; 1 NH PER CORPORATION) HAD THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC AIMS:

1. Refine the LOCK sleep program train-the-trainer protocol by implementing and pilot-testing in three NHs.
2. Test and refine the research methods to: effectively identify eligible NHs and residents; obtain consent; collect primary data from residents and staff (sleep time via actigraph); explore staff impressions of additional sleep measurement devices (Fitbits); transfer primary and secondary data to our data center; and merge all data.

participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Participants were recruited from the three participating community nursing homes. Nursing home staff referred residents to the study that they identified as meeting eligibility criteria.

groups.title: LOCK Sleep Intervention
groups.description:
Nursing home staff receive the LOCK sleep intervention training and thus provide to nursing home residents with dementia the LOCK sleep intervention

LOCK sleep intervention: Nursing home staff are trained to use a collaborative problem-solving approach to sleep quality improvement using front-line huddling

otherEvents.notes: Participant found watch uncomfortable and communicated desire to have watch removed (either through words or nonverbally by repeatedly pulling at watch)

explanation_target: Reason: The described R61 pilot (preparing an R33) tests the LOCK program — an evidence-based frontline staff huddling intervention — specifically to improve sleep in nursing home residents with Alzheimer’s disease or related dementias. This is a non-pharmacologic, implementation/behavioral intervention aimed at a symptom (sleep disturbance), not at core AD pathology or cognition. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Key extracted details — Intervention name: LOCK (frontline staff huddling program); Intervention type: non-drug, staff/organizational behavioral implementation; Primary outcome: resident sleep quality measured by actigraphy; Secondary outcomes include psychotropic/hypnotic medication use. Because the trial tests a care-delivery/behavioral program rather than a biologic or small molecule or a cognition-specific pharmacologic enhancer, there is no drug or placebo to report. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Reflect: Classification rationale — Falls under 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' because improving sleep addresses a behavioral/neuropsychiatric symptom of dementia (and the intervention is explicitly a frontline huddling program to improve sleep). It does not target Alzheimer’s pathology (so not a disease-targeted biologic or small molecule) nor is it presented as a cognitive-enhancing drug. Web search sources used to verify the trial protocol and intervention: the BMC Geriatrics study protocol and PubMed abstract. citeturn0search0turn0search3
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial describes the LOCK frontline staff huddling program — a non‑pharmacologic, implementation/behavioral intervention designed to improve sleep quality in nursing‑home residents with dementia. It targets a neuropsychiatric symptom (sleep disturbance) and not a molecular or biological pathway (e.g., amyloid, tau, inflammation, synaptic receptors). citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted details — Intervention name: LOCK (frontline staff huddling program); Intervention type: non‑drug, staff/organizational behavioral implementation; Primary outcome: resident sleep quality assessed by actigraphy; Secondary outcomes include psychotropic/hypnotic medication use and ADL decline. Because no drug, biologic, or molecular target is tested, there is no CADRO disease‑mechanism category applicable. citeturn0search6turn0search2

Reflect: Classification rationale — This is an implementation/care‑delivery trial addressing a behavioral/neuropsychiatric symptom of dementia (sleep). Per the instructions, non‑therapeutic or care‑delivery interventions that do not target a biological pathway should be classified as 'T) Other'. The NIH project record also categorizes this work under dementia care/impact (implementation), confirming the focus is on care delivery rather than a molecular target. citeturn0search5turn0search3
